{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3300419,"name":"Max","username":"Maxb0tbeep","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/maxb0tbeep/{size}/243723_2.png","created_at":"2024-02-02T19:02:12.814Z","cooked":"

Hello, I’m on the software division for team 3482. Just for fun, I am trying to play a midi file on our robot’s motors. I know this is possible with CTRE Talons but our bot is entirely using sparks at the moment, and REVLib doesn’t support midi playback. Would it be possible to parse the midi file and convert it into motor movements? Has anyone else done this before?

Is it possible, technically speaking, any stepper or brushless motor should be capable or doing this type of sounding. However as of now CTRE and the Nidec (that no one uses) support it with a custom library.

Bringing Brushless Feature Parity to the FIRST Robotics Competition Motors
Since 2020, certain brands of brushless motors have enjoyed features that other brands have not implemented. Today, I have made progress towards closing that gap. https://i.imgur.com/tZrPSsc.mp4 MicroPython code: nidecMario.py (3.2 KB) White wire connects to pin 17, blue wire connects to pin 19. This should fit nicely together, except for the red wire hanging off of the side. I hope this can finally bring the featuresets of legal brushless motors closer together. If anyone else does anythin…

Given how @bobbysq made the Nidec version I’m wondering what was involved behind the scenes to try and do the same for a SparkMax/Neo/Vortex.

Would love to have parity across all of the brushless brands on this.

Instructables

Make Music With Stepper Motors!

Make Music With Stepper Motors!: Have you seen those videos where the music was played by rotating motors? I have, so i wanted to make my own 'motor music player'. But when I started to search for some tutorials or information of how to make...

Hackaday – 15 Aug 20

Four Steppers Make A Four-Voice MIDI Instrument

Any owner of a budget 3D printer will tell you that they can be pretty noisy devices, due to their combinations of stepper motors and drives chosen for cost rather than quiet. But what if the noise…

kingc95:

Given how @bobbysq made the Nidec version I’m wondering what was involved behind the scenes to try and do the same for a SparkMax/Neo/Vortex.

This was possible with the Nidec Dynamo because of how its controller works. I don’t know the exact intricacies of how it works from an electrical perspective, but the controller passes the PWM signal directly to the motor, which means I can change the tone the motor makes when set to 0 power by changing the frequency of the PWM signal. As far as I know, REV’s controllers don’t have any way to manipulate this as an end user, so this would be difficult to implement on your own.
